category_summary:
Major product launches dominated today's AI discourse. **OpenAI** [officially released the **Codex app**](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-4fe7d6ab0def) for macOS‚Äîa multi-agent 'command center' that **Sam Altman** called 'a bigger step forward than I imagined.' **xAI** announced a merger with **SpaceX** ('One Team') and [launched **Grok Imagine 1.0**](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-2d8e9dcd5e02) with 10-second video generation at 720p.

- **Sam Altman** [shared a rare vulnerable moment](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-f03908479219): after building an app with Codex, he felt 'a little useless and sad' when AI suggested better features than he could imagine
- **Ethan Mollick** [argued](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-3b9870fbd715) that 'eulogies for AI capability growth after GPT-5' were premature‚Äîagentic harnesses are driving continued gains
- **Mollick** also [reported engineering managers](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-127bbc47e959) describing 'teams of 2 doing the work of 20 people in half the time'
- **Demis Hassabis** [announced **Kaggle Game Arena**](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-b9562668bad8) benchmarks (werewolf, poker, chess) to test AI planning under uncertainty
- **Simon Willison** [provided hands-on technical analysis](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-a14875afe476) of Codex app's SQLite architecture and automation features
- **Altman** [addressed NVIDIA relationship rumors](/?date=2026-02-03&category=social#item-abd5eed45211), affirming OpenAI hopes to remain a 'gigantic customer'
category_summary_html:
Major product launches dominated today's AI discourse. OpenAI officially released the Codex app for macOS‚Äîa multi-agent 'command center' that Sam Altman called 'a bigger step forward than I imagined.' xAI announced a merger with SpaceX ('One Team') and launched Grok Imagine 1.0 with 10-second video generation at 720p.

  • Sam Altman shared a rare vulnerable moment: after building an app with Codex, he felt 'a little useless and sad' when AI suggested better features than he could imagine
  • Ethan Mollick argued that 'eulogies for AI capability growth after GPT-5' were premature‚Äîagentic harnesses are driving continued gains
  • Mollick also reported engineering managers describing 'teams of 2 doing the work of 20 people in half the time'
  • Demis Hassabis announced Kaggle Game Arena benchmarks (werewolf, poker, chess) to test AI planning under uncertainty
  • Simon Willison provided hands-on technical analysis of Codex app's SQLite architecture and automation features
  • Altman addressed NVIDIA relationship rumors, affirming OpenAI hopes to remain a 'gigantic customer'

items.title: The many eulogies for AI capability growth after the release of GPT-5 seem especially short-sighted ...
items.content:
The many eulogies for AI capability growth after the release of GPT-5 seem especially short-sighted right now, and it created voluntary blinders for many people.

Models have advanced a lot since summer, but, more importantly, good agentic harnesses seem to lead to capability leaps on their own.
items.author: @emollick.bsky.social
items.summary: Ethan Mollick argues that 'eulogies for AI capability growth after GPT-5' were short-sighted, noting that agentic harnesses are leading to capability leaps independent of underlying model improvements
items.reasoning: Highly influential AI researcher making key observation about agentic AI driving capability gains. Highest engagement (139 likes). Directly challenges AI skeptic narratives with specific technical insight.

items.content_html:
The many eulogies for AI capability growth after the release of GPT-5 seem especially short-sighted right now, and it created voluntary blinders for many people.

Models have advanced a lot since summer, but, more importantly, good agentic harnesses seem to lead to capability leaps on their own.

items.title:
I am very excited about AI, but to go off-script for a minute:

I built an app with Codex last week....
items.content:
I am very excited about AI, but to go off-script for a minute:

I built an app with Codex last week. It was very fun. Then I started asking it for ideas for new features and at least a couple of them were better than I was thinking of.

I felt a little useless and it was sad.

I felt a little useless and it was sad.

items.title: You can totally point out that some aspects of AI are overhyped, you can believe that AGI is not pos...
items.content:
You can totally point out that some aspects of AI are overhyped, you can believe that AGI is not possible, you can criticize how the companies and governments developing AI are using or being coopted by these tools. There is a lot to criticize.

But "it doesn't work and is fake" is just wrong now.
items.author: @emollick.bsky.social
items.summary: Mollick states definitively that 'it doesn't work and is fake' criticism of AI is now simply wrong, while acknowledging valid criticisms about hype, AGI skepticism, and corporate behavior
items.reasoning: Strong, high-engagement statement (127 likes) from credible Wharton researcher pushing back on AI skepticism with clear boundaries on what criticism IS valid.
items.summary_html: Mollick states definitively that 'it doesn't work and is fake' criticism of AI is now simply wrong, while acknowledging valid criticisms about hype, AGI skepticism, and corporate behavior
items.content_html:
You can totally point out that some aspects of AI are overhyped, you can believe that AGI is not possible, you can criticize how the companies and governments developing AI are using or being coopted by these tools. There is a lot to criticize.

But "it doesn't work and is fake" is just wrong now.

items.title: On self-reports? Ive spoken to engineering managers at senior levels who are telling me about teams ...
items.content:
On self-reports? Ive spoken to engineering managers at senior levels who are telling me about teams of 2 doing the work of 20 people in half the time, Fortune 100 C-teams saying they are seeing millions in ROI

The issue is not model ability in many cases, it is organizational capacity to integrate

items.title: Just bizarre to me that there is such a large market for "AI will go away on its own" at this stage....
items.content: Just bizarre to me that there is such a large market for "AI will go away on its own" at this stage. And that so few people who serve that market seem to have updated their beliefs at all in the past year, even as key tasks like coding have already started to change beyond recognition.

items.title: As someone at a business school, I have a foot in academia and one in the world of organizations. I ...

items.title: NanoClaw fixes a couple complaints people have about OpenClaw - it's a minimal, hackable reproductio...
items.content:
NanoClaw fixes a couple complaints people have about OpenClaw - it's a minimal, hackable reproduction (700LOC), that uses Apple Containers for sandboxing/security.

currently using deepwiki codemaps to explore the codebase. highly recommend interactive learning with on-demand Q&A rather than reading someone else's interpretation of the code. the map is very much not the territory here.

items.summary_html: swyx introduces NanoClaw - a minimal 700 LOC reproduction of OpenClaw using Apple Containers for sandboxing, recommends deepwiki codemaps for interactive codebase exploration
items.content_html:
NanoClaw fixes a couple complaints people have about OpenClaw - it's a minimal, hackable reproduction (700LOC), that uses Apple Containers for sandboxing/security.

currently using deepwiki codemaps to explore the codebase. highly recommend interactive learning with on-demand Q&A rather than reading someone else's interpretation of the code. the map is very much not the territory here.

items.title: I've been trying to reimplement a very simple *classical* ML algorithm (no, not XGBoost) in a differ...
items.content: I've been trying to reimplement a very simple *classical* ML algorithm (no, not XGBoost) in a different programming language. I've been using Codex for it. It keeps resorting to writing a *neural network* implementation, even though that approach is several orders of magnitude less efficient than what is called for in this case. Even worse, the final algorithm gives me predictions that seem to be completely random with AUC of about 0.50. This reinforces my intuition that the current SOTA for ML code with AI is utter rubbish. These systems have absolutely *NO* intuition for what makes good ML.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz criticizes AI coding assistants (specifically Codex) for ML tasks, noting it keeps defaulting to neural network implementations for simple classical ML problems, producing random-level predictions (AUC ~0.50). Claims current SOTA for ML code generation is 'utter rubbish' with no intuition for good ML.
items.reasoning: Valuable technical critique from a Kaggle grandmaster on real limitations of AI coding tools for ML work. High engagement (164 likes, 14K views) and provides concrete, reproducible failure case.
items.summary_html: Tunguz criticizes AI coding assistants (specifically Codex) for ML tasks, noting it keeps defaulting to neural network implementations for simple classical ML problems, producing random-level predictions (AUC ~0.50). items.content_html: I've been trying to reimplement a very simple *classical* ML algorithm (no, not XGBoost) in a different programming language. I've been using Codex for it. It keeps resorting to writing a *neural network* implementation, even though that approach is several orders of magnitude less efficient than what is called for in this case. Even worse, the final algorithm gives me predictions that seem to be completely random with AUC of about 0.50. This reinforces my intuition that the current SOTA for ML code with AI is utter rubbish. These systems have absolutely *NO* intuition for what makes good ML.

items.title: My most productive AI workflow is literally just complaining to Claude for 3 paragraphs then typing ...
items.content:
My most productive AI workflow is literally just complaining to Claude for 3 paragraphs then typing "help me fix this plz."

üëâ Rant about your day and ask for help prioritizing.
üëâ Rant about a project and ask for blindspots.
üëâ Rant about your business and ask Claude Code to build you custom commands that save at least 2h per week.
üëâ Rant about your leads and have Claude Cowork walk you through better validation methods.
üëâ Rant about a new hire and get a science-backed call script for their 360 review.
üëâ Rant about theories for business shifts + connect Claude Code via Slack/Gmail MCP and have it test your theories against a comms timeline.
üëâ Rant about a blocker and ask for a round table of 20 agents that represent your stakeholders and a few experts to talk it through with.

Structured time for AI ranting is the secret to shipping.

items.title:
I've been trying to move from imperative prompting to declarative prompting.

‚Ä¢ Imperative prompting...
items.content:
I've been trying to move from imperative prompting to declarative prompting.

‚Ä¢ Imperative prompting: I tell the agent how to do something.
‚Ä¢ Declarative prompting: I describe my goal to the agent.

This was impossible before, but since Opus 4.5, I'm letting models fill in the blanks more and more.

I recorded a video using Quest + Opus 4.5. This is a coding agent designed specifically for this purpose.

items.summary: Santiago discusses shift from imperative to declarative prompting, enabled by Claude Opus 4.5

items.title:
A decentralized AI computer is an exponential learning machine.

Each node can discover a way to imp...
items.content:
A decentralized AI computer is an exponential learning machine.

Each node can discover a way to improve itself. Test its theories. And report its results with each other.

The whole network will improve together.

Exponentially quickly.

If you are going to compete with it you have only days to convince same number to load it, even if your system learns faster at first it will never catch up.

@openclaw is all that.

The most disruptive computing system I have ever seen turned on.

@karpathy was right to hype it up.

items.content_html:
A decentralized AI computer is an exponential learning machine.

Each node can discover a way to improve itself. Test its theories. And report its results with each other.

The whole network will improve together.

Exponentially quickly.

If you are going to compete with it you have only days to convince same number to load it, even if your system learns faster at first it will never catch up.

@openclaw is all that.

The most disruptive computing system I have ever seen turned on.

@karpathy was right to hype it up.

items.title: I remember ~2.5 years ago, with @_lewtun and @edwardbeeching and co at @huggingface how it took mont...
items.content:
I remember ~2.5 years ago, with @_lewtun and @edwardbeeching and co at @huggingface how it took months to get DPO working right.

Today, coding agents can build an entire repository from scratch, referencing high-quality implementations and discussing trade-offs, and run a representative training job on your desk. This was a 1B model on thousands of samples.

It really changes accessibility to AI research and tinkering, along with what it means to work in AI. 

I just merged the PR for this which adds a bunch of direct alignment algorithms (DPO etc) to the rlhfbook code repo, and it's remarkable how much easier this is today.

I'm feeling even more confident about what the book is becoming -- a dense place for intuitions for what actually works with models, free of hallucinations and hypes. Students can use this as a reference beside code and experiments that the AI models can spin up in an afternoon.

At its best, the RLHF Book will become a central place for people to discuss, iterate, and make community around this learning material.
items.author: @natolambert
items.summary: Nathan Lambert reflects on AI research accessibility: what took months 2.5 years ago (DPO implementation) coding agents can now build in an afternoon. Discusses RLHF Book progress.
items.reasoning: Insightful reflection from respected RLHF researcher on how coding agents are democratizing AI research. Shows concrete productivity gains.
items.summary_html: Nathan Lambert reflects on AI research accessibility: what took months 2.5 years ago (DPO implementation) coding agents can now build in an afternoon. Discusses RLHF Book progress.
items.content_html:
I remember ~2.5 years ago, with @_lewtun and @edwardbeeching and co at @huggingface how it took months to get DPO working right.

Today, coding agents can build an entire repository from scratch, referencing high-quality implementations and discussing trade-offs, and run a representative training job on your desk. This was a 1B model on thousands of samples.

It really changes accessibility to AI research and tinkering, along with what it means to work in AI.

I just merged the PR for this which adds a bunch of direct alignment algorithms (DPO etc) to the rlhfbook code repo, and it's remarkable how much easier this is today.

I'm feeling even more confident about what the book is becoming -- a dense place for intuitions for what actually works with models, free of hallucinations and hypes. Students can use this as a reference beside code and experiments that the AI models can spin up in an afternoon.

At its best, the RLHF Book will become a central place for people to discuss, iterate, and make community around this learning material.

Answering "I'm a software developer" to "What do you do in life?" two years ago was like saying "I'm a dentist"; today, it is like saying "I'm an influencer" or "I'm an online content creator."

items.title: I built a simple paralegal agent to detect, classify, and extract information from court filingsüßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è...
items.content:
I built a simple paralegal agent to detect, classify, and extract information from court filingsüßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è- complaints, motions, orders, and more!

Wrote a prompt in English, and it encoded it into a deterministic, repeatable workflow that you can use to run on millions of court filings at scale.

1. A new docket entry arrives
2. Detect what type of filing it is (motion/order/complaint/etc)
3. Define a separate schema for each new filing
4. Synthesize results in a UI with human review. Can also plug it in as an API into your workflows

This is available to everyone in our LlamaCloud agents builder. The prompt is exactly what you see in the screenshot; you can make it more/less verbose if you‚Äôd like. Come check it out!

LlamaCloud by @llama_index: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

items.content:
NEW: SpaceX just acquired xAI üöÄ

Elon's thesis: Earth can't power AI's future, so move the data centers to space 

‚Äî 1M satellites operating as orbital compute 
‚Äî Starship launching hourly at 200 tons per flight 
‚Äî 100 gigawatts of AI capacity added annually  

He predicts space-based compute will be cheaper than traditional data centers within 2-3 years  

The long-term vision involves Moon factories, Mars cities, and "harnessing the Sun's full power". 

Data centers in space sound wild, but Musk isn't alone in exploring the idea (re: Google's Project Suncatcher) ‚Äî and nobody is better positioned to actually pull it off.

Honestly, I think that skills are what make Claude Code special.

Skills gives you the ability to "compound" your leverage. As you learn more, you can have the agent do more and do it better.

Lovart adding skills is a really smart move.

I'm convinced we'll see everyone doing the same.

items.title: Even if we believe that the losses and new hires due to AI were accurately identified and not confus...
items.content:
Even if we believe that the losses and new hires due to AI were accurately identified and not confused with any other reason (this belief is obviously false due to the complexity of the modern global economy), the net loss is so small that it can be attributed to random variations: this month it's 4%, next month it will be -4%.

The unusual whales continue spreading bullshit disguised as news.

items.title:
This is how Quest works:

1. You describe what you want to build
2. Quest figures out an execution p...
items.content:
This is how Quest works:

1. You describe what you want to build
2. Quest figures out an execution plan
3. It uses specialized agents to solve tasks in parallel
4. It keeps you updated in real time as it makes progress

My favorite feature is having the ability to decide where to run the agents:

‚Ä¢ Locally: Agents run in parallel on my computer over my codebase.
‚Ä¢ Worktree: Agents run on my computer over a copy of my codebase.
‚Ä¢ Remote: Agents run remotely. Perfect for long-running tasks.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago explains Quest coding agent workflow: describe goals, parallel agent execution with local/worktree/remote options
items.reasoning: Useful technical breakdown of agent execution modes. Shows evolution of coding agent architectures with flexible deployment options.
items.summary_html: Santiago explains Quest coding agent workflow: describe goals, parallel agent execution with local/worktree/remote options
items.content_html:
This is how Quest works:

1. You describe what you want to build

2. Quest figures out an execution plan

3. It uses specialized agents to solve tasks in parallel

4. It keeps you updated in real time as it makes progress

My favorite feature is having the ability to decide where to run the agents:

‚Ä¢ Locally: Agents run in parallel on my computer over my codebase.

‚Ä¢ Worktree: Agents run on my computer over a copy of my codebase.

‚Ä¢ Remote: Agents run remotely. Perfect for long-running tasks.

But I also think it undervalues the practical, pragmatic amount of...
items.content:
I like this critique of my post!

But I also think it undervalues the practical, pragmatic amount of work AI can do right now (even including its error rate).

My fear remains that thoughtful critics don't see the the full risks (& benefits) of AI because they do not see its current effectiveness.

what's the end game of the ai reply guy?

are they trying to get people to follow them? are they loo...
items.content:
what's the end game of the ai reply guy?

are they trying to get people to follow them? are they looking to build reputation? are they just after a $1.32 monthly payout?

what is in this for them?

from my point of view, it's very obvious they are using ai to reply, especially when you see them more than once in your comments.

very low quality posts. word salads that say nothing of value.

i block them or ignore them. i suspect many people do the same.

they are making this place worse for everyone else.

so what is this about?

items.title:
SpaceX puts things in space.

Starlink runs them.

XAI will bring personalized everything to you via...
items.content:
SpaceX puts things in space.

Starlink runs them.

XAI will bring personalized everything to you via those. Hosted in space. Where packets go around earth more reliably.

No Russian ship to cut the fiber.

The everything app will make a lot of sense in three years.

When cognitive enhancements arrive.

I love this merger.

At @rackspace a truck hit our datacenter and took it down.

This system will be more reliable.

Watch trust scores go up over time.

Which turns into relevance.

Relevance is what I invest in.

But @robotaxi and @Tesla_Optimus along with everything else (trucks, batteries, solar) will be highly profitable.

So I am not selling my Tesla to buy.

Will sell everything else first.

But my money manager says no.

items.title: @wholemars On the day that Steve Jobs introduced the first iPhone, I interviewed BlackBerry's CEO. H...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer draws parallel between iPhone disrupting BlackBerry and current tech disruption, recalling interviewing BlackBerry CEO on iPhone launch day
items.reasoning: Historical tech perspective from industry veteran. Relevant pattern-matching for AI disruption narratives.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer draws parallel between iPhone disrupting BlackBerry and current tech disruption, recalling interviewing BlackBerry CEO on iPhone launch day
items.content_html:
@wholemars On the day that Steve Jobs introduced the first iPhone, I interviewed BlackBerry's CEO. He said that Apple didn't matter‚Äîthat all the CTOs were buying BlackBerry and that the iPhone didn't have a keyboard, among other arrogant things.

Well, we all know how that worked out.

I remember taking shit from so many people who said, "I'll never buy a phone without a keyboard." They were all wrong. Just like they're wrong about Tesla, and just like they were wrong about so many things in my career.

items.title:
AI is now the interface.

Not a menu, not a workflow, not a dashboard.

A conversation.

This shift ...
items.content:
AI is now the interface.

Not a menu, not a workflow, not a dashboard.

A conversation.

This shift is bigger than most teams realize, because it removes the need for users to learn the product.

Here is what that unlocks‚Ä¶

The aha moment I took away from my conversation with Amy Lokey, CXO at @ServiceNow.

#ServiceNowPartner

items.title:
@Noahpinion The issue started long before social media. 
It started with Reagan's cancellation of th...
items.content:
@Noahpinion The issue started long before social media. 
It started with Reagan's cancellation of the FCC Fairness Doctrine, which opened the door to divisive propaganda outlets like Fox News and conservative talk radio. 
Then, badly run social media like this one made things worse. 
But political polarization in the US started increasing over 40 years ago.
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: Yann LeCun argues political polarization predates social media, blaming Reagan's FCC Fairness Doctrine cancellation enabling Fox News
items.reasoning: Political commentary from AI leader, tangentially related to tech platforms.
items.summary_html: Yann LeCun argues political polarization predates social media, blaming Reagan's FCC Fairness Doctrine cancellation enabling Fox News
items.content_html:
@Noahpinion The issue started long before social media.

It started with Reagan's cancellation of the FCC Fairness Doctrine, which opened the door to divisive propaganda outlets like Fox News and conservative talk radio.

Then, badly run social media like this one made things worse.

But political polarization in the US started increasing over 40 years ago.

items.title: Fun fact, the person responsible for this is a Russian asset, Gerhard Schr√∂der (see 2002 Atomgesetz)...
items.content:
Fun fact, the person responsible for this is a Russian asset, Gerhard Schr√∂der (see 2002 Atomgesetz) and the purpose of the move was to ensure German energy dependence on Russia.

He became chairman of the board of Rosneft and NordStream, and was about to join the board of Gasprom before the war started. He made tens of millions from Russian energy companies and pro-Putin lobbying. Lifelong friend with Putin, whom he lauded as a flawless democrat in 2004.

items.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet details Gerhard Schr√∂der's role as Russian asset responsible for German energy dependence on Russia, his positions at Rosneft and NordStream
items.reasoning: Not AI-related - geopolitical commentary on German-Russian relations.

items.content_html:
Fun fact, the person responsible for this is a Russian asset, Gerhard Schr√∂der (see 2002 Atomgesetz) and the purpose of the move was to ensure German energy dependence on Russia.

He became chairman of the board of Rosneft and NordStream, and was about to join the board of Gasprom before the war started. He made tens of millions from Russian energy companies and pro-Putin lobbying. Lifelong friend with Putin, whom he lauded as a flawless democrat in 2004.

We both agreed to keep real estate agents out of it

Saved us both a giant commission for doing zero work

Best decision of my life

items.title:
@akarlin I'm pro-migration

But I prefer having migration that actually benefits the host country an...
items.content:
@akarlin I'm pro-migration

But I prefer having migration that actually benefits the host country and respects its capacity

Skilled workers, investors, students, digital nomads with proof of income and insurance, these are win-win

Unfiltered mass influx that turns high-trust welfare states into magnets for the global poor is not, because no country can afford that, not financially, but also not socially as you see now all over Western Europe and especially Germany!

Supporting selective, high-value migration while opposing uncontrolled low-quality mass migration is not hypocrite I think, it's just common sense

Personally I've never committed any crimes not at home in Netherlands and not abroad, I've spent literally millions all over the world, also millions in taxes, and I've always tried to respect local culture, customs and assimilate as much as possible

In Portugal where I live I've learnt the history, culture and language and also contributed millions $$$ of my money

I've also never taken welfare

So yes I think digital nomads are a net positive, and I for sure am

Are you losing talent because your systems still look like 2005?

At @Acumatica Summit, Paul Tadford...
items.content:
Are you losing talent because your systems still look like 2005?

At @Acumatica Summit, Paul Tadford, CEO of @SR_MFG_ERP shared a hard truth: manufacturers are losing young talent because employees won‚Äôt learn outdated tech.

After helping 2,000+ companies modernize ERP, Paul sees the same pattern:
üî¥ 30% of the manufacturing workforce is 55+
üî¥ Manufacturing is the #1 ransomware target
üî¥ Companies start with tech instead of strategy
The winners do 3 things differently.

I break down Paul‚Äôs framework in this week‚Äôs #CXOSpice newsletter + our conversation üëá

https://t.co/Z2e5MM3yfH

 or https://t.co/0emX9fVZBb

#Manufacturing #CloudERP #DigitalTransformation #AcumaticaSummit #AI

items.content:
And building apps becomes just as intuitive.

One of the most powerful ideas Amy shared:

You can design an app in Figma, drop it into the build agent, and generate an enterprise grade application.

The product creation loop shrinks from weeks to minutes.

This changes how teams prototype, iterate, and deliver.

items.title:
This flexibility does more than simplify workflows.

It collapses user friction.

When a support age...
items.content:
This flexibility does more than simplify workflows.

It collapses user friction.

When a support agent can drop a screenshot, or a field engineer can describe an issue with voice, or a business user can upload a document, AI handles the complexity behind the scenes.

Technology finally meets people where they are.

items.title:
Under the hood, the model does one powerful thing:

It splits sound into two parts ‚Üí

‚Üí The target s...
items.content:
Under the hood, the model does one powerful thing:

It splits sound into two parts ‚Üí

‚Üí The target sound
‚Üí Everything else

That single capability unlocks a lot ‚Üí

‚Üí Faster editing for creators
‚Üí Cleaner, more controllable data for AI training
‚Üí Multimodal systems that understand sound like visuals

This is basically segmentation, but for audio.

This is basically segmentation, but for audio.

items.title:
The big unlock is simple but profound:

Instead of forcing humans to adapt to audio tools, the model...
items.content:
The big unlock is simple but profound:

Instead of forcing humans to adapt to audio tools, the model adapts to human intent.

You can guide it three ways ‚Üí

‚Üí Type what you want, like ‚Äúkeep only the voice‚Äù
‚Üí Click where the sound happens in the video
‚Üí Mark a moment in time and say, the sound I care about is here

No guesswork. No fragile presets.

Not tweaking EQs.
Not guessing with filt...

What if cleaning audio was as easy as clicking on a pixel?

Not tweaking EQs.
Not guessing with filters.

Just pointing to the sound you want, and telling the AI, keep this.

items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: @BenjaminDEKR I have been invited to hundreds of parties in my career. I've never Googled anybody who ran a party; I just assume they're good. Now, some parties, you know, are a little crazier than ot...
items.summary_html: @BenjaminDEKR I have been invited to hundreds of parties in my career. I've never Googled anybody who ran a party; I just assume they're good. Now, some parties, you know, are a little crazier than ot...
items.content_html:
@BenjaminDEKR I have been invited to hundreds of parties in my career. I've never Googled anybody who ran a party; I just assume they're good. Now, some parties, you know, are a little crazier than others, but I probably still wouldn't have checked it out.

Especially if a whole bunch of other important people were already going. The social proof on these things makes you turn off your brain.

That said, eventually you figure it out‚Äîparticularly when you get passports sent to you with children's pictures in them. Right.

items.title: @micahsb @wholemars The BlackBerry gave me carpal tunnel because I was typing on it underneath table...
items.content:
@micahsb @wholemars The BlackBerry gave me carpal tunnel because I was typing on it underneath tables at business meetings. I was a power user and one of the first, but I eventually had to give it up because of my carpal tunnel.

Now I use @typelessdotcom with my voice and I'm way faster than you are on any keyboard.

items.title: Or maybe I am wrong! I think I have been pretty good at predicting the implications of AI over the p...
items.content:
Or maybe I am wrong! I think I have been pretty good at predicting the implications of AI over the past few years, but AI is now too big for any one person to get their hands around, so who knows?

But if I am not wrong, we are missing a chance in academia to weigh in at a very important moment.

items.title: It will take awhile before any of these changes have real implications - organizations are slow to c...
items.content:
It will take awhile before any of these changes have real implications - organizations are slow to change - but I think the current models are enough to see large-scale changes in employment and jobs in the next few years. Most economists who are up to date on AI agree.

Guiding this is urgent.

items.title: I don't see any indication that AI companies could not be profitable on inference if they stopped tr...
items.content:
I don't see any indication that AI companies could not be profitable on inference if they stopped training right now (not that they are doing so), or that agentic harnesses on so-so models may not make them capable

Also, costs keep dropping. I don't think this is a long term Uber issue economically

items.title:
I like this critique!

But I also think it underestimates the practical, pragmatic amount of work AI...
items.content:
I like this critique!

But I also think it underestimates the practical, pragmatic amount of work AI can do right now (even including its error rate). My fear remains that thoughtful critics don't see the the full risks (& benefits) of AI because they do not see its current effectiveness at work.

That is why I think it would make a thrilling video game.

items.title:
I was feeling bad since wednesday but started feeling normal yesterday afternoon

A few possibilitie...
items.content:
I was feeling bad since wednesday but started feeling normal yesterday afternoon

A few possibilities:
- I started keto saturday, but likely entered ketosis sunday
- I started neurofeedback therapy on sunday
- I started a new supplement stack including sporanox (mold killer) on sunday
- or naturally I would have recovered anyway without help

items.title:
I'm so done with real estate agents

What an absolutely useless profession in 2026

Nowadays when I ...
items.content:
I'm so done with real estate agents

What an absolutely useless profession in 2026

Nowadays when I go visit houses to buy you get the construction company guy tell you everything anyway, and they actually know their stuff

And then you have some literally low IQ shady car salesman guy hovering around you in the back with NO added information and NO added service

"Yes this house is great because it's north-facing"

And then for doing absolutely nothing zilch nada, they deserve 5% of the house price in commission???

And you can't visit the house direct because real estate agents cover each other asses so the selling agent will tell you to find a buyer agent to be able to visit it

A complete racket 100%

items.title:
Germany has a 115 year history of repeated mass psychosis through ideological totalitarianism 

Germ...
items.content:
Germany has a 115 year history of repeated mass psychosis through ideological totalitarianism 

German culture raises people who pursue ideas with extreme thoroughness and moral intensity

WW2 was nationalism brought to its extreme resulting in millions of people dead

Now we have the same ideological totalitarianism regarding sustainability, emissions, climate change and immigration

They keep destroying Europe

items.content:
You absolutely cannot trust Germans with nukes

Did we learn anything from history? I'm Dutch so I sure as hell did when we were invaded by them

French yes, British yes  they can have nukes, they're trustworthy, not Germans

They'll start behavior policing the entire EU with nuclear weapons as a threat

Absofuckinglutely not

items.content:
üáßüá∑ My favorite thing about Brazil is the buffets

They're everywhere and you can get fresh made whole foods like meat and vegetables priced per kilogram

And with nice medium rare steak usually

Here's my almost 1kg/2lbs regular lunch every day

One difference with buffets rest of world where I'd never ever touch buffets there because the food is usually old and stale, in Brazil it's almost always fresh and hot

It's a bit like the Warungs in Indonesia btw
